Mr. Clinton began the day in Moscow with an address to both chambers of the Russian Parliament, in which he said that ''Americans have to overcome the temptation to think that we have all the answers.''

Leaving President Clinton behind in Moscow, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia flew to Rome to sell Europe -- and the Vatican -- on a Russian alternative to the United States missile defense proposal. Mr. Putin also hoped to attract European investment in the Russian economy.

In France, Urging a Shorter Term President Jacques Chirac proposed shortening the presidential term to five years from seven, which could alter the nature of French politics and help him in the next elections.

Support for Africa Pipeline The World Bank, with American support, is expected to approve a $3.5 billion oil pipeline project for Chad and Cameroon, in West Africa, despite concern about possible corruption and environmental damage.

Pressing Both Sides in Mideast Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright arrived in Jerusalem to inject a sense of urgency into the long-running Israeli-Palestinian negotiations and to lay the foundation for a three-way summit meeting.

O.A.S. Delegation to Peru Foreign ministers of the Americas, meeting in Canada, agreed to send a mission to Lima to explore options for strengthening democracy in Peru. The team is to be led by two critics of the May 28 voting that resulted in the unopposed re-election of Alberto Fujimori as president.
Hillary Clinton at U.N. Hillary Rodham Clinton delivered a spirited speech on women's rights at the United Nations, at one of many meetings of a weeklong special session on the progress of women.

Court Limits State Law On Expanded Visiting Right The Supreme Court, voting 6 to 3, ruled that a Washington State law went too far in permitting a judge to order visiting rights for grandparents over a mother's objection. The justices declared that parents have a ''fundamental right to make decisions concerning the care, custody and control'' of their children.

Ruling Against Ken Starr The Supreme Court ruled, 8 to 1, that the office of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, had violated an immunity agreement with Webster L. Hubbell by forcing Mr. Hubbell to produce thousands of pages of personal financial records and then using those records to indict him on charges of tax evasion.

Staying on the Sideline Ross Perot, the founder of the Reform Party and its two-time presidential candidate, has all but ruled out running against Patrick J. Buchanan for the party nomination this year, a spokesman said.

Gore at New York Fund-Raiser Vice President Al Gore helped raise $3.7 million for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee at a Manhattan event. Earlier, he proposed putting nearly all federal government services online.

Boom in Political Donations Campaign fund-raising continued to reach new highs as both parties almost doubled the soft-money totals raised in the last presidential year, and House and Senate candidates also set records in the 15 months that ended March 31.

Judge Quits Secrets Case The 66-year-old federal judge who was to oversee the trial of Wen Ho Lee, accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets, said he was recusing himself to assume senior status, a form of semiretirement.
Kentucky Prosecutor Slain A man charged with child molesting and the prosecutor who was about to try him were killed in a gunfight at the prosecutor's home hours before they were to meet in court.

New Jersey Lawmakers Balk at Census Sampling The Republican-controlled Assembly voted to require the state to use data only from mailed-in census forms, door-to-door canvassing or other traditional means to redraw Congressional and state districts.

A City Budget Agreement Mayor Giuliani and the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, announced a $37.6 billion budget accord that uses a record surplus to help cut business and income taxes and still expands government services.

Last Louima Trial Begins The third and final criminal trial arising from the attack on Abner Louima opened as federal prosecutors asserted that Police Officer Francisco Rosario had lied to investigators about what he saw.

Pitcher Demoted to Minors The Atlanta Braves sent John Rocker to the minor leagues and fined him $5,000, one day after he confronted the reporter who wrote the Sports Illustrated article that quoted him as denigrating various groups.
Plea Deal in Atlanta Murder and assault charges against the Baltimore Ravens star Ray Lewis were dropped as he pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor and agreed to testify against two co-defendants.
Devils One Victory Away The Devils beat the Dallas Stars, 3-1, in Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals, to take a 3-1 lead in the four-of-seven-game series.

Communications Merger The F.C.C. approved AT&T's acquisition of MediaOne, after ordering the companies to sell some assets. The action clears the final obstacle to a merger that will create the nation's largest provider of cable television, long-distance telephone service and high-speed Net access. The decision angered some consumer groups.

Bestfoods Weighs Better Offer The Bestfoods board met to discuss a sweetened takeover offer of $72 a share, or about $20 billion, from Unilever, as pressure from shareholders grew to sell the company.

Bias Cited at Investment Bank The E.E.O.C. said Morgan Stanley Dean Witter had discriminated against women working in its institutional stocks division, opening the door for lawsuits -- and possibly a class action -- against the firm.
